org.jtuples

Class Functions

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jtuples.Functions

  • public final class Functions
extends Object
    This class provides static methods to support a functional programming style. It provides methods commonly seen in functional programming environments, that revolve around the use of tuples and functions (or lambdas).
    Author:
    Andre Santos

    • Method Detail

      • curry

        public static <A,B,C> BiFunction<A,B,C> curry(Function<Pair<A,B>,C> function)
        Returns a curried version of the given function. Given a function that accepts a pair as its argument, its curried version is a function that accepts the two components of the pair individually. That is, given a function f: ((a, b)) -> c, it becomes g: (a, b) -> f((a, b)) instead.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the type of the first component of the pair
        B - the type of the second component of the pair
        C - the return type
        Parameters:
        function - the function to curry
        Returns:
        the curried version of the given function

      • uncurry

        public static <A,B,C> Function<Pair<A,B>,C> uncurry(BiFunction<A,B,C> function)
        Returns an uncurried version of the given function. Given a function that accepts two individual parameters, its uncurried version accepts instead a pair consisting of the two parameters. That is, given a function f: (a, b) -> c, it becomes g: ((a, b)) -> f(a, b) instead.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the type of the first parameter
        B - the type of the second parameter
        C - the return type
        Parameters:
        function - the function to uncurry
        Returns:
        the uncurried version of the given function

      • split

        public static <A,B,C> Function<A,Pair<B,C>> split(Function<A,B> f,
                                                  Function<? super A,C> g)
        Returns the split of the two given functions. Given two functions with parameters of the same type, the split of such functions is a single function, with the same parameters, that returns a pair whose components are the application of the original functions to the arguments. That is, given functions f: (a) -> b and g: (a) -> c, they become h: (a) -> (f(a), g(a)) instead.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the type of the parameter
        B - the return type of the first function
        C - the return type of the second function
        Parameters:
        f - the first function of the split
        g - the second function of the split
        Returns:
        the split of the given functions

      • split

        public static <A,B,C,D> BiFunction<A,B,Pair<C,D>> split(BiFunction<A,B,C> f,
                                                        BiFunction<? super A,? super B,D> g)
        Returns the split of the two given functions. Given two functions with parameters of the same type, the split of such functions is a single function, with the same parameters, that returns a pair whose components are the application of the original functions to the arguments. That is, given functions f: (a, b) -> c and g: (a, b) -> d, they become h: (a, b) -> (f(a, b), g(a, b)) instead. Note that this, in a way, is equivalent to the product of the given functions, although simplified.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the type of the first parameter
        B - the type of the second parameter
        C - the return type of the first function
        D - the return type of the second function
        Parameters:
        f - the first function of the split
        g - the second function of the split
        Returns:
        the split of the given functions

      • split

        public static <A,B> Supplier<Pair<A,B>> split(Supplier<A> f,
                                              Supplier<B> g)
        Returns the split of the two given functions. Given two functions with parameters of the same type, the split of such functions is a single function, with the same parameters, that returns a pair whose components are the application of the original functions to the arguments. That is, given functions f: () -> a and g: () -> b, they become h: () -> (f(), g()) instead. Note that this is equivalent to the product of suppliers.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the return type of the first function
        B - the return type of the second function
        Parameters:
        f - the first function of the split
        g - the second function of the split
        Returns:
        the split of the given functions

      • product

        public static <A,B,C,D> Function<Pair<A,C>,Pair<B,D>> product(Function<A,B> f,
                                                              Function<C,D> g)
        Returns the product of the two given functions. Given two functions, the product of such functions is a single function, with the union of the parameters, as a Pair, that returns a pair whose components are the application of the original functions to the respective arguments. That is, given functions f: (a) -> b and g: (c) -> d, they become h: ((a, c)) -> (f(a), g(c)) instead.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the type of the parameter of the first function
        B - the return type of the first function
        C - the type of the parameter of the second function
        D - the return type of the second function
        Parameters:
        f - the first function of the product
        g - the second function of the product
        Returns:
        the product of the given functions

      • product

        public static <F1,F2,G1,G2,F,G> BiFunction<Pair<F1,G1>,Pair<F2,G2>,Pair<F,G>> product(BiFunction<F1,F2,F> f,
                                                                                      BiFunction<G1,G2,G> g)
        Returns the product of the two given functions. Given two functions, the product of such functions is a single function, with the union of the parameters, as a Pair, that returns a pair whose components are the application of the original functions to the respective arguments. That is, given functions f: (a, b) -> c and g: (d, e) -> f, they become h: ((a, d), (b, e)) -> (f(a, b), g(d, e)) instead.
        Type Parameters:
        F1 - the type of the first parameter of the first function
        F2 - the type of the second parameter of the first function
        F - the return type of the first function
        G1 - the type of the first parameter of the second function
        G2 - the type of the second parameter of the second function
        G - the return type of the second function
        Parameters:
        f - the first function of the product
        g - the second function of the product
        Returns:
        the product of the given functions

      • product

        public static <A,B> Supplier<Pair<A,B>> product(Supplier<A> f,
                                                Supplier<B> g)
        Returns the product of the two given functions. Given two functions, the product of such functions is a single function, with the union of the parameters, as a Pair, that returns a pair whose components are the application of the original functions to the respective arguments. That is, given functions f: () -> a and g: () -> b, they become h: () -> (f(), g()) instead. Note that this is equivalent of the split of suppliers.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the return type of the first function
        B - the return type of the second function
        Parameters:
        f - the first function of the split
        g - the second function of the split
        Returns:
        the split of the given functions

      • product

        public static <A,B> Consumer<Pair<A,B>> product(Consumer<A> f,
                                                Consumer<B> g)
        Returns the product of the two given functions. Given two functions, the product of such functions is a single function, with the union of the parameters, as a Pair, that returns a pair whose components are the application of the original functions to the respective arguments. That is, given functions f: (a) -> void and g: (b) -> void, they become h: ((a, b)) -> (void) (f(a), g(b)) instead.
        Type Parameters:
        A - the type of the parameter of the first function
        B - the type of the parameter of the second function
        Parameters:
        f - the first function of the split
        g - the second function of the split
        Returns:
        the split of the given functions
